name: Configure SCIM for Okta
title: Configure SCIM for Okta
body:
In this article, you’ll learn how to configure SCIM for Okta. Configuring SCIM for Okta allows you to use Okta to manage users in your KSAT console. For information on how to enable SCIM for your KSAT console, see our SCIM Configuration Guide.

The instructions below are for third-party software. If you experience issues with user provisioning in Okta, we recommend reaching out to Okta for specific instructions. You can also contact our support team and we will be happy to assist you.

Important:Some customers may not have the ability to enable SCIM provisioning on custom apps. If the option does not display, you will need to contact Okta support to have them enable this feature for your organization. For more information on this, see Okta's Add SCIM provisioning to app integrations article.

Configuring SCIM

After you have configured your SCIM settings in your KSAT Account Settings, you are now ready to configure SCIM for Okta. To configure SCIM for Okta, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Okta portal and navigate to Applications.
  2. Click Browse App Catalog. 
  3. In the search bar, enter “KnowBe4” to filter the results.
  4. Select the KnowBe4 app.
Note: If you already have a KnowBe4 SAML app in Okta, you can leave this app as-is.
Important: If you’re adding the provisioning capability to an already existing custom SAML app, you’ll need to provision the existing users before they can log in. To provision existing users, you’ll need to go to the Assignments tab on the app’s configuration page and select Provision User.
  1. Click Add Integration.
  2. Edit the name and settings, if you would like.
  3. Click Done.
  4. Navigate to the Provisioning tab.
  5. Click the Integration subsection.
  6. Click Configure API Integration.
  7. Select the Enable API integration check box.
  8. Paste the Tenant URL from your KSAT Account Settings into the SCIM connector base URL field. To learn how to access your Tenant URL, see the Configuring SCIM section of our SCIM Configuration Guide.
  9. Paste the SCIM token from your KSAT Account Settings into the API Token field. To learn how to access your SCIM Token, see the Configuring SCIM section of our SCIM Configuration Guide.
  10. Click Test API Credentials.
  11. A message will display to notify you whether the test succeeded or failed. If the test succeeded, click Save.
  12. Now that you have set up the connection between your KSAT console and Okta, you can enable the services that you want to manage through Okta. To get started, click To App.
  13. Click Edit on the right side of the Provisioning to App section.
  14. Select the Enable check box for each feature that you would like to use.
Important: Pushing groups in Okta has some limitations that may affect your SCIM operation. For more information on this issue, see Okta’s About Group Push article.
Important: We do not currently support Sync Password. Any passwords that are sent with this setting will not be accepted.

After you have configured SCIM for Okta, you will need to choose which users to sync. To learn more about syncing users through Okta, see the Defining Which Users and Groups to Sync section below.

Defining Which Users and Groups to Sync

After you have followed the steps in the Configuring SCIM section above, you can define which users and groups you would like to sync. Defining which users and groups to sync is required before you can sync users from your identity provider.

Important:If you define groups, we recommend leaving additional group attributes blank. If you leave these additional attributes blank, individual users' attributes will be synced in place of the blank attributes. If you set up a group attribute for the following fields, the group attribute will override any individual user attributes for the users assigned.

To define which users and groups to sync, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Okta portal and navigate to Applications.
  2. Click the SCIM application that you created in the Configure SCIM section above.
  3. Navigate to the Assignments tab.
  4. Click Assign to select which users you would like to sync.
  5. Click either Assign to People or Assign to Groups, depending on whether you want to define users or groups.
  6. Select the users or groups that you would like to sync.
Important: For your first sync, we recommend that you only select a few users or groups.
  1. Click Assign.
  2. After you select the user or group that you would like to sync, click Save and Go Back.
  3. After you’ve added all the users and groups that you would like to include, click Done.

Any users and groups you selected will now display in the Assignments tab.

Defining Which Groups to Sync

To sync groups and group memberships from Okta to your KSAT console, follow the steps below.

Important:We do not currently support the Push now button. Clicking this button may remove memberships from selected groups.
  1. Log in to your Okta portal and navigate to Applications.
  2. Click the SCIM application that you created in the Configure SCIM section above.
  3. Click Push Groups.
Important: Okta does not support using the same groups for assignments and group push. For more information, see Okta’s About Group Push article.
  1. From the drop-down menu that opens, select Find groups by name.
  2. Enter the names of groups you would like to sync.
  3. Click Save.

Attribute Mappings

In Okta, there are attribute mappings that you can customize in order to define which fields sync between Okta and your KSAT console. To modify these attribute mappings, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Okta portal and navigate to Applications.
  2. Click the SCIM application that you created in the Configure SCIM section above.
  3. Click Provisioning.
  4. Click To App.
  5. Scroll down to Attribute Mappings.
  6. Make the changes that you would like to make.
  7. Save your changes.
Important:We recommend that you download a CSV file from the Users tab in your KSAT console to have a backup of all user field info in case of an unexpected error.

You may have fields in your KSAT console that you don’t want to update from Okta. As a best practice, we recommend that you remove these attribute mappings so that they aren’t updated during an Okta sync.

For more information about Okta attribute mappings, see the Advanced Configuration Options section below.

Starting Your Sync

After you’ve configured your SCIM settings and added the users and groups that you want to sync, you can start the sync. After you’ve started the first sync, syncs from Okta will occur automatically. You can also manually force a sync from your Okta portal at any time.

Note: If you have more than several thousand users in your SCIM provisioning application, it’s likely all of your users won't be included in your initial sync. Instead, the users will be synced to your account in stages. We recommend that you keep user provisioning in Test Mode until you see only a few changes between your sync reports. Waiting until you only see a few changes helps prevents users from being archived in your KSAT console. Additionally, syncing group memberships can take longer than syncing users. If you have a larger account, you can expect to see periodic syncs in your KSAT console.

To start your sync, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Okta portal and navigate to Applications.
  2. Click the SCIM application that you created in the Configure SCIM section above.
  3. Click Provisioning.
  4. Click Force Sync.

The sync will be initiated immediately. After your initial sync, syncs will occur automatically when you change user information in Okta.

Important:Once you are satisfied that your users have synced correctly, you’ll need to turn off Test Mode in your KSAT Account Settings. Turning off Test Mode will allow users to be added and archived during the next sync. For more information about Test Mode, see our SCIM Configuration Guide.

Once your sync has started, you can view the sync status and learn about any errors from the Provisioning tab in your KSAT console. To learn more about the Provisioning tab, see our How to Use the Provisioning Tab article.

Advanced Configuration Options

You can customize your Okta configuration by changing default field mappings, adding custom attributes, or mapping custom KnowBe4 fields. For more information about customizing your Okta configuration, see the subsections below.

Important:Email aliases are not currently supported by SCIM provisioning. 

Changing the Default Field Mappings

You have the option to change the default field mappings. The default field mappings are listed in the table below:

KSAT Field SCIM Attribute Okta Field
Email userName userName
First Name givenName user.firstName
Last Name familyName user.lastName
Phone Number primaryPhone user.primaryPhone
Location formatted user.postalAddress
Division division user.division
Employee Number employeeNumber user.employeeNumber
Job Title title user.title
Organization organization user.organization
Department department user.department
Mobile Phone Number mobilePhone user.mobilePhone
Manager Display Name managerDisplayName user.manager
Manager Email managerEmail user.managerId
KSAT Field Okta Field SCIM Attribute
Time Zone N/A N/A
Extension N/A N/A
Language N/A N/A
Comment N/A N/A
Employee Start Date N/A N/A

To change the default field mappings, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Okta portal and navigate to Applications.
  2. Click the SCIM application that you created in the Configure SCIM section above.
  3. Click Provisioning.
  4. Select To App.
  5. Navigate to the Attribute Mappings section.
  6. Click the pencil icon to map a new Okta field to the SCIM attribute.

Adding Custom Attributes

To add new custom attributes to the KnowBe4 provisioning application in Okta, follow the steps below:

  1. Log into your Okta admin console.
  2. Navigate to Applications and select the KnowBe4 SCIM application that you created in the Configuring SCIM section above.
  3. Click Provisioning, then under the Mappings section, click Go to Profile Editor.
  4. In the Profile Editor, click Add Mapping. An Add Attribute modal will open.
  5. Select the attribute mapping you would like to add. We offer the following additional attribute mappings in Okta, which are displayed below:
    Display name Variable name External namespace
    Company Name companyName urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:knowbe4:kmsat:2.0:User
    Country country urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:knowbe4:kmsat:2.0:User
    Employee Type userType urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:core:2.0:User
    Hostname hostname urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:knowbe4:kmsat:2.0:User
    Mail Nickname mailNickName urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:knowbe4:kmsat:2.0:User
    SAM Account Name onPremisesSamAccountName urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:knowbe4:kmsat:2.0:User
    Security Identifier onPremisesSecurityIdentifier urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:knowbe4:kmsat:2.0:User
    User Principal Name userPrincipalName urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:knowbe4:kmsat:2.0:User
    Last Password Change lastPasswordChangeDateTime

    urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:knowbe4:kmsat:2.0:User
  6. To configure your attribute mapping in the Add Attribute modal, see the screenshot and list below:

    1. Data type: Select String as the Data type for your attribute mapping.

    2. Display name: Enter the Display name for your attribute mapping.

    3. Variable name: Enter the Variable name for your attribute mapping. This variable will be sent from Okta to the KnowBe4 provisioning app.

      Tip:Typing in the Variable name field will automatically fill in the External name field.

    4. External name: Enter the Variable name for your attribute mapping. The External name field should be the same as the Variable name field.

      Tip:Typing in the Variable name field will automatically fill in the External name field.

    5. External namespace: Enter the External namespace value for your attribute mapping.

      Note:The External namespace value must exactly match the value in the table. We recommend copying and pasting the value.

    6. Save: Click Save to add your new attribute mapping.

  7. Click Save Mappings to apply your changes.
  8. Map your new attributes by following the Mapping Custom Fields section below.

Mapping Custom Fields

You also have the option to map custom fields to sync with your KSAT console.

These fields are not mapped by default, but you can add them to your Okta platform by following the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Okta portal and navigate to Applications.
  2. Click the SCIM application that you created in the Configure SCIM section above.
  3. Click Provisioning.
  4. Scroll down and click on Show Unmapped Attributes.
  5. Click the pencil icon next to any of the attributes that you would like to add.
  6. From the Attribute value drop-down menu, select the Okta attribute that you would like to map to each custom field.
  7. Click Save.
Note: If you are configuring a Custom Date attribute, the date must be formatted in ISO 8601 format. The format is as follows: YYYY-MM-DD “T” hh:mm:ssZ. For example, 2022-04-04T04:23:30Z.

If you need any help using this feature, please contact our support team.

images.alt:
This document describes the application detail page for **KnowBe4** within a corporate application catalog interface (likely Okta).

**Context and Navigation (UI Elements):**
*   **Breadcrumb Navigation:** The hierarchy is displayed as `Applications > Catalog > Single Sign-On > KnowBe4`.
*   **Update Timestamp:** The integration metadata includes the text "Last updated: October 15, 2021."
*   **Primary CTA:** A prominent blue button in the top right, labeled "**Add Integration**" and featuring a plus icon, serves as the primary call-to-action.

**Application Identification:**
*   **Name and Tags:** The application is titled **KnowBe4**. Associated technical tags are displayed: `SAML` and `SCIM`.
*   **Verification Status:** A dedicated section is labeled **Okta Verified** (accompanied by a checkmark icon), indicating the integration has been tested and verified by the platform provider.

**Functional Details:**
*   **Use Case:** Listed use cases, presented as hyperlinks, are **Single Sign-On** and **Lifecycle Management**.
*   **Functionality:** Supported protocols, presented as hyperlinks, are **SAML** (Security Assertion Markup Language) and **SCIM** (System for Cross-domain Identity Management).
*   **Overview:** The description defines KnowBe4 as a security awareness training and simulated phishing platform, emphasizing that the Okta integration enables single sign-on and user provisioning to manage users and groups within the KnowBe4 console.

The image displays a system configuration screen for an external API integration, specifically with KnowBe4.

**UI Elements and Text:**

1.  **Header:** The screen is titled "Integration." A navigational link, "Cancel," is located in the upper right corner.
2.  **API Enablement:** A checkbox labeled "**Enable API integration**" is present and currently checked (active).
3.  **Instructional Text:** A line of text reads: "Enter your KnowBe4 credentials to enable user import and provisioning features."
4.  **Input Fields:**
    *   **Base URL:** A text input field for the base endpoint (content is partially obscured/redacted).
    *   **API Token:** A masked input field for the API key (content is obscured by black dots).
5.  **Validation Action:** A button labeled "**Test API Credentials**" is displayed below the input fields, allowing the user to validate the connection setup.
6.  **Primary Action:** A primary, blue button labeled "**Save**" is located in the bottom right corner of the interface.
images.context: If the test succeeded, click Save.

images.alt:
This image displays the Okta application provisioning settings for the KnowBe4 integration.

**Context and UI Flow:**
The top of the screen visually confirms the data flow: **Okta** $\rightarrow$ **KnowBe4**. An unannotated edit link labeled **Edit** is visible on the upper right side, allowing modification of these settings.

**Provisioning to App Settings:**
The main configuration header is **Provisioning to App**. All listed provisioning capabilities below are currently inactive, as indicated by the presence of an unchecked, disabled **Enable** checkbox next to each section.

1.  **Create Users:**
    *   **Description:** Creates or links a user in KnowBe4 upon app assignment in Okta.
    *   **Configuration Detail:** The **default username** is explicitly set to the **Okta username**.

2.  **Update User Attributes:**
    *   **Description:** Okta updates attributes in KnowBe4 upon app assignment. Subsequent attribute changes in the Okta user profile will automatically overwrite corresponding values in KnowBe4.

3.  **Deactivate Users:**
    *   **Description:** Deactivates the KnowBe4 account when the application is unassigned in Okta or if the associated Okta account is deactivated. Accounts can be reactivated through subsequent reassignment.

images.alt:
This image displays a segment of a management interface focusing on assignment functionality and a list view.

**Header and Action Controls:**

*   **Assign Button (Active):** A prominent blue button labeled "Assign ▼" is visible on the far left, indicating an active state.
*   **Dropdown Menu:** A white dropdown menu is deployed from the "Assign" button, featuring two options:
    1.  "Assign to People"
    2.  "Assign to Groups"
*   **Convert Assignments Button:** Adjacent to the Assign button is a standard button labeled "Convert assignments ▼".
*   **Search Bar:** A global search input box is present on the right, containing the placeholder text "Search...".
*   **Context Filter:** A blue button labeled "People ▼" is located next to the search bar, likely controlling the scope of the displayed list.

**Content List (Table View):**

*   **Side Panel Elements:** Text fragments suggest a vertical filter or navigation panel on the left ("Groups" visible).
*   **Table Structure:** The main area displays a list view with a header row defining the column "Type".
*   **Data Rows:** Four visible rows are displayed, each representing an entity.
    *   Each row features a user silhouette icon and a blurred identifier (redacted data).
    *   The "Type" column for all visible entries is explicitly listed as **"Group"**.
    *   **Actions:** Each row contains two interactive icons on the far right: a blue pencil icon (indicating an edit function) and a light gray 'X' icon (indicating a delete or removal function).
images.context: o People or Assign to Groups, depending on whether you want to define users or groups.

images.alt:
This image displays a UI segment for managing and pushing application groups within a dashboard environment.

**Control Panel Elements (Top Row):**
The primary navigation controls include a set of action buttons:
1.  **Push Groups** (Active, blue primary button with a dropdown indicator).
2.  **Refresh App Groups** (Secondary button).
3.  **Bulk Edit** (Secondary button).
4.  **Settings** (Gear icon button).
5.  A right-aligned search bar labeled **Search...**.

**Active Dropdown Menu (Push Groups):**
The dropdown menu from the **Push Groups** button offers two methods for group selection, both prefixed with a green plus icon:
1.  **Find groups by name:** *Search for specific groups to push.*
2.  **Find groups by rule:** *Create a search rule that pushes any groups that match the rule.*

**Data Grid (List View):**
The area below the controls displays a data grid listing application groups, organized by columns:
*   [Group Name/Identifier (redacted)]
*   [Description (partially visible, including text `l for SCIM` and `No description`)]
*   **Last Push** (Redacted data)
*   **Push Status** (Displays the value `Active` in green, followed by a dropdown arrow and a blue information icon).

images.alt:
This excerpt of a UI displays configuration options for **Attribute Mappings** within an identity management context.

### UI Context and Text Elements

*   **Header:** The page title is displayed in bold text: **Attribute Mappings**.
*   **Instructional Text:** Below the header, the instruction reads: "Select a(n) [CENSORED] attribute to set its value based on values stored in Okta." (Note: Specific contextual text relating to the attribute type is redacted.)

### Action Buttons

Two primary action buttons are presented as blue-bordered elements:

1.  **Button 1 (Profile Editor Access):**
    *   **Label:** **Go to Profile Editor**
    *   **Iconography:** Preceded by a small pencil/edit icon ($\text{\text{Go to Profile Editor}}$).
2.  **Button 2 (Synchronization Trigger):**
    *   **Label:** **Force Sync**
    *   **Iconography:** Preceded by a circular refresh/synchronization arrow icon ($\text{\text{Force Sync}}$).

*   **Annotation:** A large, red arrow is visually overlaid on the image, pointing specifically toward the **Force Sync** button, indicating it as the targeted or primary action for this segment.
images.context:
CIM section above.
Click Provisioning.
Click Force Sync.

images.alt:
This image displays a **User Provisioning Sync Reports** interface, specifically focused on the provisioning synchronization log.

**Header and Context:**
*   **Title:** "User Provisioning Sync Reports" (accompanied by a user icon).
*   **Status Messages:**
    *   A green message indicates: "SCIM provisioning is enabled in Account Settings" (SCIM icon visible).
    *   A red caution message indicates: "Test Mode is enabled in Account Settings" (test tube/beaker icon visible). Both "Account Settings" are hyperlinks.
*   **Navigation Tabs:** A tab bar includes links for "Users," "Groups," "Import Users," the active tab **"Provisioning,"** and "Merge Users."

**Data Table (Provisioning Sync Reports):**
The table tracks synchronization events with the following columns (sortable via up/down arrows and featuring tooltips/help icons):

1.  **Sync Received:** Displays the timestamp of the synchronization event (e.g., "09/10/2020 5:36 PM").
2.  **Status:** Displays the sync result using status tags (e.g., "Completed" in a green badge).
3.  **Groups:** Shows the number of groups processed.
    *   Row 1: "1"
    *   Row 2: "-" (dash)
4.  **Users:** Shows the number of users processed, with errors highlighted.
    *   Both visible rows show: "7" followed by a red badge containing "**4 errors**".
5.  **Memberships:** Shows the number of memberships processed.
    *   Row 1: "2"
    *   Row 2: "-" (dash)
6.  **Service:** Indicates the provisioning service used ("SCIM - SCIM").
7.  **Test Mode:** Confirms if the sync was run in test mode (indicated by a red badge with a test tube icon and the text "**Test**").
8.  **Action:** A standard blue button labeled "**Details**" (with a list icon) is available for each row to view comprehensive logs.

**Content:** The table lists two completed synchronization events, both run on September 10, 2020, and both resulting in 4 user errors while operating in Test Mode via the SCIM protocol.
images.context: /support.knowbe4.com/hc/en-us/articles/4408867460371' target='_self'>How to Use the Provisioning Tab

images.alt:
This image displays the **Attribute Mappings** configuration interface for an identity management system, specifically detailing how attributes for "CL 6/8 US anc.cool" are set based on values stored in Okta.

**Context and Actions:**

*   **Header:** "Attribute Mappings."
*   **Instructional Text:** "Select a(n) CL 6/8 US anc.cool attribute to set its value based on values stored in Okta."
*   **Buttons (Top Actions):**
    1.  **Go to Profile Editor** (Primary blue button with a pencil icon).
    2.  **Force Sync** (Secondary button with a circular refresh icon).

**Attribute Mapping Table:**

The core of the UI is a four-column data table detailing the configured attribute synchronization:

| Column Header | Description of Data |
| :--- | :--- |
| **Attribute** | Displays the user-friendly attribute name (e.g., Username, Given name) followed by the system variable (e.g., `userName`, `givenName`). |
| **Attribute Type** | Categorizes the attribute (all displayed are "Personal"). |
| **Value** | Shows the Okta source attribute or configuration status. |
| **Apply on** | Defines the conditions under which the mapping is applied (Create, Update, or both). |

**Specific Mappings Detailed:**

1.  **Username:** Value is defined as "Configured in Sign On settings" (where "Sign On settings" is a hyperlink, indicating external configuration).
2.  **Given name (`givenName`):** Value is mapped to the Okta source `user.firstName`. The mapping is applied on "Create and update."
3.  **Family name (`familyName`):** Value is mapped to the Okta source `user.lastName`. The mapping is applied on "Create and update."

**Row Actions:**

For the "Given name" and "Family name" rows, the last column contains two functional icons, visible for editing and removal:
*   **Edit Icon:** A small blue pencil icon to modify the mapping.
*   **Delete Icon:** A small blue 'X' icon to remove the mapping.

*(Note: A large red arrow points to the edit and delete icons in the "Given name" row.)*

Click the pencil icon to map a new Okta field to the SCIM attribute.

images.alt:
This document describes the user interface for the "Add Attribute" configuration panel.

**Title and Context:**
The screen title is **Add Attribute**. A crucial informational note is displayed below the title: "*Local app attributes are only stored on Okta and not created in KnowBe4. Use local attributes if you plan to add the attribute to KnowBe4 or only want to store the mapped value in Okta."

**Configuration Fields:**
The interface utilizes a two-column layout for parameter definition (Label on the left, Control on the right). Several input fields include an associated information/help icon (indicated by a question mark).

| Field Label | UI Element Type | Default/Current Value | Notes |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Data type** | Dropdown Menu | string | Labeled (a) in the source image. |
| **Display name** | Text Input | Empty | Labeled (b). Requires user input. |
| **Variable name** | Text Input | Empty | Labeled (c). Requires user input. |
| **External name** | Text Input | Empty | Labeled (d). Requires user input. |
| **External namespace** | Text Input | Empty | Labeled (e). Requires user input. |
| **Description** | Text Input | Empty | Optional descriptive text field. |
| **Enum** | Checkbox | Unchecked | Paired with the label: "Define enumerated list of values". |
| **Attribute length** | Dropdown Menu | Between | Controls min/max text fields below it. |
| (Min value) | Text Input | min (placeholder) | Sub-field for Attribute length. |
| (Max value) | Text Input | max (placeholder) | Sub-field for Attribute length. |
| **Attribute required** | Radio Button | Unselected (Yes) | Determines if a value is mandatory. |
| **Attribute type** | Radio Button Group | Personal (Selected) | Includes the option "Group" and explanatory text: "Most attributes are personal. Only select Group if you want to set the value of this attribute at a group level." |

**Action Buttons (Footer):**
The footer contains three action controls, preceded by an application-specific icon:

1.  **Save** (Blue primary button)
2.  **Save and Add Another** (Blue primary button)
3.  **Cancel** (Text link)

images.alt:
This image displays a segment of a user interface for attribute management and data mapping, presented as a configuration table against a white background.

**Structure and Content:**

*   The view consists of six rows representing custom attributes, separated by thin gray dividers. Each attribute name is listed twice in the first column (e.g., `customField1` followed by the same name in smaller text below it).
*   The second column consistently shows the category `Group` for all listed attributes.
*   The third column indicates the current mapping status for both the primary and secondary fields as `Not mapped`. This text is rendered in light gray, suggesting a default or inactive state.

**Interactive Elements:**

*   The far right of each row features two interactive icons:
    1.  A blue pencil icon (representing 'Edit' or 'Map Attribute').
    2.  A light blue 'X' icon (representing 'Delete' or 'Remove Attribute').
*   A prominent red arrow is overlaid on the image, specifically pointing to the blue pencil icon associated with the `customField4` row.

**Footer Element:**

*   Below the configuration list, a blue hyperlinked text button is visible: `Hide Unmapped Attributes`. This suggests that the current view is listing attributes that require mapping.

images.alt:
This image displays a configuration screen section for managing a custom attribute or field within a user interface.

**Header/Title:**
The top section features a bold title indicating the context: a blurred, greyed-out identifier followed by the specific field name, **"- customField3"**.

**Input Fields (Configuration):**
Below the title, there is a field labeled **"Attribute value"**.
*   Associated with this label is a dropdown select box displaying the placeholder text: **"Select a type..."** A small downward-pointing arrow indicates the expandable nature of the input.

**Action Bar/Footer:**
The bottom of the displayed section includes two primary components:
1.  **Preview/Input Control:** A compound control, presumably for entering and viewing the attribute's value. The left half is a button labeled **"Preview"** and includes an eye icon. The right half is an empty text input box.
2.  **Control Buttons:** Located in the bottom right corner are standard action buttons:
    *   A primary button, colored blue, labeled **"Save"**.
    *   A secondary text link labeled **"Cancel"**.
images.context: ute value drop-down menu, select the Okta attribute that you would like to map to each custom field.
